name: Dodona
shortDescription: Ancient oracle of Zeus in Epirus where priestesses interpreted divine will through rustling oak leaves
fullDescription: Dodona was Zeus's oracle sanctuary in Epirus, northwestern Greece‚Äîarguably Greece's oldest oracle, predating even Delphi. The site centered on a sacred oak grove where priestesses called Selli (or Peleiades, 'doves') interpreted Zeus's messages through the rustling of oak leaves, the cooing of doves, and the ringing of bronze vessels. According to legend, Zeus's first oracle began when two black doves flew from Egyptian Thebes‚Äîone to Dodona, one to the oracle of Ammon in Libya. The sanctuary's rustic simplicity contrasted with Delphi's grandeur, reflecting Zeus's role as both sky god and protector of agriculture. Pilgrims consulted Dodona on matters ranging from personal concerns to state affairs, receiving responses through the sacred oaks' voice.

originPoint.name: Dodona
originPoint.description: Ancient oracle sanctuary of Zeus in Epirus, northwestern Greece, near modern Ioannina. Site features sacred oak grove, temple of Zeus, and theatre. Arguably Greece's oldest oracle, predating Delphi.

firstAttestation.description: Homer's Iliad (Book 16.233-235) mentions Dodona as established oracle of Zeus

timelinePosition.context: Oracle active from at least Early Bronze Age (archaeological evidence c. 2000 BCE), mentioned as ancient in Homer (c. 750 BCE), closed by Christian emperor Theodosius I (391 CE)

keyMoments.significance: Iliad describes Dodona as Zeus's oracular oak grove
First stone temple of Zeus built at Dodona
King Pyrrhus of Epirus expands sanctuary and builds theatre
Theodosius I bans pagan oracles; Dodona abandoned
